snippet.textDisplay: There are a lot of Linux apps that already work fine on ARM PCs. (There are a lot of apps already ported to the architecture.) Assuming Microsoft hasn't done something to kill future installation of Linux on this thing, I suspect that that might be the way forward for these, at least in the short term. Microsoft will get it right eventually, I'm sure, but they've basically built a really nice Linux tablet and tried to force it to run Windows when Windows isn't yet ready.
snippet.textOriginal: There are a lot of Linux apps that already work fine on ARM PCs. (There are a lot of apps already ported to the architecture.) Assuming Microsoft hasn't done something to kill future installation of Linux on this thing, I suspect that that might be the way forward for these, at least in the short term. Microsoft will get it right eventually, I'm sure, but they've basically built a really nice Linux tablet and tried to force it to run Windows when Windows isn't yet ready.

snippet.textDisplay: I can tell that LTT wants to make Intel feel like it needs to do better to keep up with its competitors, but the takeaway from every video I've seen lately of new devices using AMD or ARM-based chips seem to show Intel as still being well ahead of the pack, and will likely continue to be so unless AMD and ARM start to heavily discount their products (which, in this case, it doesn't seem to have done nearly enough to make the Surface X an attractive price/quality proposition).
snippet.textOriginal: I can tell that LTT wants to make Intel feel like it needs to do better to keep up with its competitors, but the takeaway from every video I've seen lately of new devices using AMD or ARM-based chips seem to show Intel as still being well ahead of the pack, and will likely continue to be so unless AMD and ARM start to heavily discount their products (which, in this case, it doesn't seem to have done nearly enough to make the Surface X an attractive price/quality proposition).

snippet.textDisplay: AMD will most likely be integrating ARM cores into their CPUs at some point in the future during the migration from x86 to ARM over the next decade. x86 is too big, bloated, and power-hungry for the vast majority of applications out there. x86 is going the way of SPARC, Itanium, and Co. now.
snippet.textOriginal: AMD will most likely be integrating ARM cores into their CPUs at some point in the future during the migration from x86 to ARM over the next decade. x86 is too big, bloated, and power-hungry for the vast majority of applications out there. x86 is going the way of SPARC, Itanium, and Co. now.

snippet.textDisplay: What do you mean 80% of a full Windows device? It's more like 20%. If they could somehow get x86 apps running fast enough to be not only usable but enjoyable, I'd agree that it would be 80% of the way there. But that's not the case, and the library of ARM compatible apps is simply nowhere near what it needs to be. In fact, 20% of a full WIndows device even seems a bit generous.
snippet.textOriginal: What do you mean 80% of a full Windows device? It's more like 20%. If they could somehow get x86 apps running fast enough to be not only usable but enjoyable, I'd agree that it would be 80% of the way there. But that's not the case, and the library of ARM compatible apps is simply nowhere near what it needs to be. In fact, 20% of a full WIndows device even seems a bit generous.

snippet.textDisplay:
TL;DR: CISC processors still rule the roost for performance. However elegant RISC processors might seem in theory, it is simply more time-efficient to have long sequences of frequently-used instructions hardwired into the processor hardware. RISC is more power-efficient, but CISC is more powerful, and it will always be that way. Who cares about longer battery life when you spend that extra time being frustrated because the apps you need run slowly or don't run at all?
How about if they skip the emulator and just include a low-power dual-core x86-64 processor to run desktop apps?
snippet.textOriginal:
TL;DR: CISC processors still rule the roost for performance. However elegant RISC processors might seem in theory, it is simply more _time-efficient_ to have long sequences of frequently-used instructions hardwired into the processor hardware. RISC is more power-efficient, but CISC is more powerful, and it will always be that way. Who cares about longer battery life when you spend that extra time being frustrated because the apps you need run slowly or don't run at all?
How about if they skip the emulator and just include a low-power dual-core x86-64 processor to run desktop apps?

snippet.textDisplay:
funny how some people think 3:2 is a walk in the park. 5:27
I think many people actually believe it is a win-win and you don't lose anything only gaining vertical wideness.
got a shitload of these 7mm unibody Book tablets https://i.imgur.com/H8ijtSR.jpg
and measured a 13.3" +500nits 3200x1800 277PPI tablet panel from Porsche vs Surface Book2 3000x2000 - 266PPI with 13.5" and even though the SB2 with 3:2 was 0.2" inches bigger with 13.5" vs 13.3" I lost 1cm in horizontal while gaining 2.5cm in vertical and no doubt that 1cm in horizontal view was noticeable when watching media.
Sure the 13.5" was ideal when drawing etc with bigger vertical screen real-estate..but media and youtube, etc that 1cm on the 13.3" really did make quite a noticeable difference. https://i.imgur.com/ugPIAMM.jpg
In some circumstances 3:2 ideal while in others not so much..

And no the device ain't to thin for USB A port ... aint the Surface X like + 7mm? (// yep 7.3mm) so around the same as Surface Book2 at 7½mm.. - and when they can have a surface connect port, you can bet they would also have thickness for a USB A port.. perhaps they don't have room hence battery, borders etc, but lack of thickness aint the sinner ..(don't eat that sucking-cloth of an excuse from Microsoft 6:00 )
snippet.textOriginal:
funny how some people think 3:2 is a walk in the park.  5:27
I think many people actually believe it is a win-win and you don't lose anything only gaining vertical wideness.
got a shitload of these 7mm unibody Book tablets https://i.imgur.com/H8ijtSR.jpg
and measured a 13.3" +500nits 3200x1800 277PPI tablet panel from Porsche vs Surface Book2 3000x2000 - 266PPI with 13.5" and even though the SB2 with 3:2 was 0.2" inches bigger with 13.5" vs 13.3" I lost 1cm in horizontal while gaining 2.5cm in vertical and no doubt that 1cm in horizontal view was noticeable when watching media.
Sure the 13.5" was ideal when drawing etc with bigger vertical screen real-estate..but media and youtube, etc that 1cm on the 13.3" really did make quite a noticeable difference. https://i.imgur.com/ugPIAMM.jpg
In some circumstances 3:2 ideal while in others not so much..

And no the device ain't to thin for USB A port ... aint the Surface X like + 7mm? (// yep 7.3mm) so around the same as Surface Book2 at 7½mm.. - and when they can have a surface connect port, you can bet they would also have thickness for a USB A port.. perhaps they don't have room hence battery, borders etc, but lack of thickness aint the sinner ..(don't eat that sucking-cloth of an excuse from Microsoft  6:00 )

snippet.textDisplay:
Years ago, Microsoft had versions of Windows NT on RISC platforms. The X86 emulation layer executed code between half to one-third of what native code would run. But this is also in a time when the 486 was king of the desktop.

It’s good to see that there’s some progress in that respect.
snippet.textOriginal:
Years ago, Microsoft had versions of Windows NT on RISC platforms. The X86 emulation layer executed code between half to one-third of what native code would run. But this is also in a time when the 486 was king of the desktop.

It’s good to see that there’s some progress in that respect.
